title: A complete formalism for giant Goos
content: arXiv:2510.10788v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Giant Goos-H\"anchen shift is a promising effect for very highly sensitive sensors application. For sensors working at the critical coupling regime, we provide here a complete formalism that describes analytically the Goos-Hanchen shift, the Goos-H\"anchen sensitivity and the limit of detection. It reveals the key parameters (quality factor, angular dispersion but also the phase singularity) which are involved in the GH shift. Approaching the critical coupling leads to ultimate Goos-H\"anchen shift and sensitivity. Thanks to this theoretical description confirmed numerically, we propose lateral beam displacement that goes beyond giant GH shift and sensitivity values as high as $10^{13} {\mu}m/RIU$ which is an improvement of Goos-H\"anchen sensitivity by more than one thousand compared to theoretical value and more than ten million if compared to experimental works. We illustrate it for surface plasmon resonance of thin metal film where the critical coupling is approached with the crystallisation of a phase change material GST and for metasurfaces supporting Bloch Surface Waves. We also discuss the effect of beam size on GH effect and showed that it is the main limitation for increasing GH sensitivty and is a parameter that must be considered. The limit of detection of GH sensors is finally described analytically. Theses results open the way for new sensing application needing high sensitivity.

metadata.author: Lotfi Berguiga, S\'ebastien Cueff, Taha Benyattou, Xavier Letartre, C\'ecile Jamois

sustainability_analysis.reasoning: This article presents a theoretical framework for highly sensitive sensors using the giant Goos-H"anchen shift. While the theoretical description is confirmed numerically and shows potential for improved sensitivity (10^13 μm/RIU), it remains at the basic research stage with no deployed technology or real-world data. The potential climate impact is indirect, relying on the application of these sensors in environmental monitoring or other climate-related fields.
key_impact_metrics: improvement of Goos-Hanchen sensitivity by more than one thousand compared to theoretical value

title: Block cubic Newton with greedy selection
content: arXiv:2407.18150v4 Announce Type: replace Abstract: A second-order block coordinate descent method is proposed for the unconstrained minimization of an objective function with a Lipschitz continuous Hessian. At each iteration, a block of variables is selected by means of a greedy (Gauss-Southwell) rule which considers the amount of first-order stationarity violation, then an approximate minimizer of a cubic model is computed for the block update. In the proposed scheme, blocks are not required to have a predetermined structure and their size may change during the iterations. For non-convex objective functions, global convergence to stationary points is proved and a worst-case iteration complexity analysis is provided. In particular, given a tolerance $\epsilon$, we show that at most ${\cal O(\epsilon^{-3/2})}$ iterations are needed to drive the stationarity violation with respect to a selected block of variables below $\epsilon$, while at most ${\cal O(\epsilon^{-2})}$ iterations are needed to drive the stationarity violation with respect to all variables below $\epsilon$. Numerical results are finally given, comparing the proposed approach with other second-order methods and block selection rules.

key_phrases: A second-order block coordinate descent method

sustainability_analysis.reasoning: This paper proposes a new optimization algorithm that could potentially improve the efficiency of other algorithms used in climate modeling, renewable energy deployment, or other sustainability-related fields. The algorithm's performance is evaluated using worst-case iteration complexity analysis, showing at most ${\cal O(\epsilon^{-3/2})}$ iterations are needed to drive the stationarity violation with respect to a selected block of variables below $\epsilon$. However, the direct impact on sustainability is theoretical at this stage.
